&S graduate stipends cut $170,000
By BILL ABBOTT
The equivalent to 85 graduate
qipends at $2000 per annum has
fallen under the budget ax in. the
Arts and Sciences division,
according to Dean George Owen.
Owen attributed the $170,000
bullet bite in University stipend
assistance -- 20 percent the A&S
Stipend budget -- to the $300
tuition increase and anticipated
federal cutbacks.
the "It is generally recognized that
all the days grad students can
depend on the University, the
federal government, or both to
day
Lred fully support them are just about
irne Over," commented Larry Denton,
assistant to Homewood
Vice-President George Benton.
"With the increase in tuition
and the elimination of some
federal support," Denton added,

for
ved
ces
ose
25,

"we'll either have fewer grad
students or more supporting
themselves."
Denton estimated that 1
percent of Homewood's 970
graduate students currently pay
their own tuition. He speculated
that graduate enrollment next
September would decline to
about 900.
The University will increase its
spending for graduate aid next
year by $130,000, bringing its
total support to $2.42 million.
Owen explained this increase and
funds gained from the stipend
cut will be directed into the
Gilman Fellowship program, the
University's grad student tuition
assistance effort.
Denton admitted, however,
that the added $300,000 will not
be enough to fully support the

tuition needs of all Homewood
graduate students. And, by
Denton's estimate, 50 percent of
all grads now receiving stipends
had to secure outside loans
because the levels of stipend
support "couldn't support the
lowest standard of living."
One source in the Political
Science department maintained
that graduate stipends were being
cut from $2200 to $2000, and
that first year students who had
taken out loans in anticipation of
some stipend suppoi-t next year
would not get any.
Benton, whose office
determined that the University
would award the $2.42 million in
University funds, asserted that all
departments would feel the
pinch.
"We've tried to spread the pain

as evenly as possible," Benton
said, explaining that departments
which will not be affected by
federal funding cutbacks would
have to suffer at the expense of
those which are.
One source of federal funding
tapped for termination by the
new Nixon budget is the US
Public Health training grant. The
departments of Psychology,
Social Relations, Biology, and
Biophysics currently receive
$800,000 for graduate student
support through the training
grant program.
Psychology, the only
department with training grants
up for renewal this year,
anticipated to lose all of its
$67,000 now used to support 16
graduate students. However, last
Friday, department chairman

Dean George uwen
William Garvey was informed all
previous notices of curtailment
were "inoperative," and that
Psychology would be able to
support those students to whom
training grant assistance had been
committed prior to April 23 for
their graduate career.

Class of '77 has fewer pre-meds
By B.H. COHEN
This fall's incoming freshman
class, anticipated to be the largest
since the GI-bill days
immediately after World War II,
may include fewer Natural
Science and pre-medical students
than the current freshman class.
Already, 598 of the 1375
applicants accepted for the class
of 1977 have filed their $100
deposits, and additional deposits
are expected to arrive over the

next several days. In addition,
approximately 10 of the
accepted applicants have been
given extensions beyond
Tuesday's May 1 deadline for
filing deposits.
Last year, according to
Admissions and Financial Aid
Director John R. Riina, 578
students had returned deposits
by May 3, though that figure rose
to 588 at one point last May. 557
students enrolled as freshmen last
summer, some 22 more than
anticipated.
One admissions officer stated
that he expects about 618
students to file deposits by the
end of the month.
"There will be some attrition
in our yield," Riina commented
yesterday.
Figures released by Riina
indicate that the number of
Natural Science and pre-med
majors will decline somewhat
from the level of the current
freshman class. "I'm impressed
with the fact that we have fewer

pre-meds in this incoming class,
even though the total number of
students will go up," Riina
commented.
Last year at this time, 249
pre -meds had filed deposits.
Through yesterday, 243 pre-meds
had filed.
Prospective Natural Science
enrollees have fallen from 349
last year, to 335 this year, while
depositers: in the Social and
Behavioral Sciences have gone up
from 111 to 135.
In addition, tlumanities,
Engineering, and Quantitative
Studies depositers have increased
somewhat over last year's level.
[See figures, page 61
"We have more numbers vhere
we wanted better percentages,
and less where we wanted to see
a reduction," Riina explained.

year that Admissions, acting
under the guidance of
Homewood Vice President

discipline code'til fall

-

2Ctioit
,
By ALLEN SHORT
Homewood Advisory Councii
flAC) action on the new Code
Student Rights and
isciplinary Procedures appears
.ghly unlikely this semester as,

I

On

the result of a Student Council
decision postponing its
consideration of the code until
after next fall's frosh elections.
The HAC had -earlier deferred .
action on the code pending SC

Andrew S'avilz

approval and open hearings.
According to SC president
Andrew W. Savitz, the decision
reflects an SC concensus of
opinion that "The undergraduate
student body hasn't had the time
orthe opportunity to adequately
study the code."
During the discussion which
preceded the tabling decision
Tuesday night, Council members
debated the necessity of having a
discipline code.
•
Committee Came
Said HAC undergrad
representative Howard Majev,
"The Discipline Committee came
to us and said that a code was
needed, but they never said
why."
According to senior class

president-elect Shep Hoffman, a
member of the Discipline
Committee, "The present interim
code, implemented by (Arts &
Sciences) Dean Benton in 1970,
would have remained in effect
had we not come up with a new
one. We found it particularly
distasteful."
Eyes And Ears
In a related action yesterday,
some twenty-five students
attended the open hearing on the
Discipline Code and voiced
considerable dissatisfaction with
several of its provisions.
Leon Barish, newly-elected
junior class SC representative,
objected to the code's
enumeration of specific
violations, especially one

prohibiting "Illegal possession,
use, or sale of drugs or liquor on
campus." He maintained that the
provision, if enforced, would
eliminate the serving of beer -at
Sunday afternoon concerts. If
the provision is not to be
enforced, he continued, "there is
just no reason to have it in '
there."
Dean of Students Robert J.
Fitzpatrick stated that he will
recommend to the HAC next
Thursday that action on the code
be deferred until after the
beginning of next semester.
After approval has been given
to the code, in its original or
revised version, said Fitzpatrick,
it should be implemented on a
temporary basis.

Homecoming fetes
alums this week-end
By JERRY NESER
This weekend's 1973
Homecoming festivities,
sPonsored by the Office of
Alumni Relations, will include
the annual Alumni Relations
Dinner, a luncheon, and campus
tours, according to Edward 0.
Nicholas, Homecoming
Chairman.
Other features of the weekend
Will include Saturday's lacrosse
game against Navy, and reunions
of the classes whose graduating
Years end in "3" or "8", the
Oldest class represented will be
that of 1903.
"The Homecoming is geared
towards those reunion classes,"
said Bill Van Diepen, assistant
director of Alumni Relations.
The class of 1923 will definitely
be the most highlighted class,
though," he added.
Lo-Cal Desert
The Alumni Association
Dinner, to be held this evening at
the Hunt Valley Inn in
Cockeysville, will feature as
Speakers President Muller and
Louis Koerber, Alumni
Association President. Also, the
Distinguished Alumnus Awards
Will be presented during the
dinner.
Receiving the Alumni Awards

will be Albert D. Hutzler,
president of Hutzler's Brothers
and retired alumni trustee,
Edward Schaefer, an industrialist
from Indiana, and Donald
Wilson, president of Monumental
Life Insurance Company and
retiring president of the Alumni
Association.
The luncheon will be held on
Saturday afternoon with the
traditional crabcake meal
planned. Afterwards, the reunion
classes will proceed to the
Homewood Field Granstands
where the Class of 1923 will
receive 50-year medallions.
Lunchmeat
"The luncheon this year is sold
out," explained Van Diepen. "It
hasn't been sold out in years, but
we are expecting some 1500
people," he added.
Following the lacrosse game,
the Hopkins fraternities will hole
open houses for the alumni.
Saturday evening the reunion
classes will hold dinner dances
and parties on campus.
"All that I hope of the
Hopkins students is that they
remember that it is Hopkins
Alumni Homecoming," asserted
Van Diepen. "I hope that they
will cooperate with us during this
weekend," he added.

Warren to speak at graduation
Earl Warren, former Chief
Justice of the United States will
be the featured speaker at
Commencement exercises on
Friday, May 25. Warren has also
served as Attorney General and
Governor of California.
Beginning at 9:30 am the
ceremony will take place in the
Keyser quadrangle between
Gilman Hall and the Milton S.
Eisenhower Library. President
Muller will preside over the
ceremony.
During the exercises, degrees
will be conferred upon
candidates from the Medical,
• W4
,151,-.1,

Arts and Sciences, Hygiene,
Evening College, and
International Studies divisions. A
total of 2,304 degrees are
expected to be given. In addition,
472 advanced degrees will be
awarded.
tent, capable of covering
four thousand people, will be
erected so that the event may be
held outdoors, regardless of
weather.
Successful candidates for the
B.A. and the B.E.S. will have
their diplomas presented to them
at a separate ceremony on
Thursday, May 24. The featured
A

speaker will be Victor Zorza,
noted syndicated columnist and
lecturere at the School of
Advanced International Studies.
Zorza is a designer and expert in
the field of "predictive analysis."
He has gained widespread
recognition for his predictions of
some of the most unexpected
international developments in
recent years, such as the
Sino-Soviet dispute and the fall
of Soviet leader Nikita
Khruschev.
Also to receive honorary
degrees at Commencement day
ceremonies are two faculty
members emerit. Their names
were not available yesterday
since the Board of Trustees must
grant formal approval with the
awarding of the degrees. The
Board next meets on May 14.
Singing
Traditional parts of the
two-day ceremoney will include
the procession of berobed
University officials, faculty
members and graduates, and the
singing of the University ode.

Freshmen admissions exceed expectations
FROSH, from page 1

I

more deposits than anticipated
from prospective freshmen. Last
Year, Admissions was aiming for
35 enrollees. And letters to high
school guidance counsellors,
mailed early in April this year,
read in part, "only 530 places are
available for freshmen."
Student Council President
Andrew W. Savitz, reached last
Right, commented, "I'm happy
to hear that the pre-med and
natural science percentages have
gone down.
"But I hope that the Housing
,Office is able to find space for all
the freshmen next fall," he
added.
Other information released by

Riina indicates that the number
of first-year women will remain
at its present level, and that black
freshmen may increase. While
only 14 blacks enrolled last fall,
23 have already filed deposits
this year.
Five high schoolers have
elected to defer their
matriculation by up to two years,
in a newly-instituted program.
They are not included in the 598
depositors.
Riina stated that this year's
yield to date is 43.5 percent of
all accepted students, up from
last year's 40.8 percent.
However, only 78 of the top
202 applicants to this fall's class,
or 38.6 percent, Filed deposits.

goodbye, goodbye
Bob Hewes' Office of Public Information doesn't keep
statistics on them, but Hopkins officials have been disappearing from their desks at an alarming rate this year, some
moving upstairs and some just moving. This bureaucratic
phenomeno, often referred to as "the screw," rarely merits
a press release or a big story (with picture) in the Gazette.
We wonder a little how these folks are ever going to be
found when the University makes so little effort to let us
know where they went.
As a public service to our readers, we are today printing a
list of the missing and their fates in our last issue of the
year. Among the missing:
Budget Director Benjamin Ge. Willis, whose disappearance caused Garland Hall morale to plummet, disappeared
after Hopkins had its first balanced budget in five years.
Development Director David W. Ellis got lost among the
Hopkins Hundreds.
Director of Student Activities and of the Hopkins Union
Jim Sydnor, will soon get lost.
Director of Athletics Marshall S. Turner, Jr., will warm
the bench for up to two years before retirement from the
Athletic Center.
MSE Librarian John H. Berthel now keeps track of the
University Library in Garland Hall.
If the new discipline code is ever promulgated, students
may disappear ahnost as fast.

Four Hop profs elected to National Academy of Sciences
Four Hopkins professors were
among the 95 new members
elected last month to the
National Academy of Sciences.
The elections of Homewood
professors Donald D. Brown,
Biology, Robert G. Parr,
Chemistry, and Medical School
faculty members Victor A.
McKusick, professor of medicine
and Helen B. Taussig, professor
emeritus of pediatrics, bring the
total membership in the
Academy to 1,012, according to
Dr. Philip S. Handler, Academy
president.
Election to membership in the
National Academy of Sciences is
considered one of the highest
honors that can be accorded an
American scientist or engineer.
Brown, a developmental
biologist, joined the U.S. Public
Health Service Natioal Institute
of Mental Health in 1957 as S.A.
surgeon and research associate. In
1959 he was appointed Special

1951, when he was named
instructor. He was appointed
professor of medicine in 1960
and currently holds joint
appointments in biology in the
Arts and Sciences and
epidemiology at the School of
Hygiene and Public Health.

McKusick is chief of the Division
of Medical Genetics at the School
of Medicine.
McKusick's well-known
investigations include a long-term
study of hereditary diseases
among the Amish and a study of
the x chromosomes in man.
Parr joined the faculty of the

in 1947 as assistant professor and

National Science Foundation

University of Oxford in

Study at Hopkins of hemoglobin molecule yields results
A team of Hopkins
biophysicists has obtained new
data on the structure of the
sickle cell hemoglobin molecule
in the critical deoxygenated
state.
The new information was
obtained through th6 technique of
x-ray diffraction of crystallized
sickle cells.
The research group is headed
by Warner E. Love, professor and
chairman of the Department of
Biophysics and includes Eato
Lattman, a research associate,
and graduate students Keith
Ward and Barry Wishner.
Hemoglobin moleules, both
normal and sickle cell, exist in
two states in the blood stream:
oxygenated after passing through
the lungs, and deoxygenated
after they have released the
oxygen at some point in the
body.
The latter is the important
state as far as study of the
diseased molecule is concerned.
It is in this deoxygenated state

that the molecules stick together
and distort the red blood cell in
which they are contained. This
causes the painful "sickle cell
crisis" in sickle cell anemia. The
anemia is a hereditary disease
which affects approximately one
black person in forty.
According to Love, electron
microscopy does not yield
sufficient detail to reveal the
atomic structure of the molecules
and up to now,it has not been
possible to analyze them by x-ray
diffraction because of technical
difficulties in crystalizing
deoxygenated sickle cell
hemoglobin. The crystalization
process is a prerequisite for
employment of the x-ray
diffraction. Love began working
on the sickle cell problem nearly
two years ago. The research
group's initial success came last
year in January when Wishner
succeeded in growing diffraction
quality crystals of deoxygenated
sickle cell hemoglobin. As a
result of the advance, Love's

$209,000 from the National
Institutes of Health to support
further study.
A second breakthrough was
recorded last month when the
researchers discovered the proper
position of the molecule in its
crystal lattice. The problem was
achieved with the aid of
computer facilities at Hopkins
Applied Physics Lab.
Love explained that there was
an element of risk involved in the
study. "It is possible
in the
process of crystalization," he
*said, "that the hemoglobin
molecules may be altered such
that they no longer represent
what actually goes on in the
human blood stream." But Love
added that his group was hopeful
that in their study of the
molecule's crystalline structure
they will in fact come up with a
true picture of what the sickled
hemoglobin molecule looks like.

diffraction analysis will be a

THE PSYCHOLOGY CENTER has completed its
most unusual assignment — the ADULT I.Q. TEST. It
is unusual in its approach to intelligence testing.
Any test that relies on either memorization or recall
is basically an inaccurate and unreliable indicator of
intelligence. Unfortunately, this type of test is
prevalent throughout our educationai system. The
ADULT I.Q. TEST, however, is composed of
questions that are specially designed to probe and
challenge the intellect in order to reveal its ability to
think. For this reason, the ADULT I.Q. TEST is a
true intelligence test.

Matthews stands tall as best of 'last barrier
By MIKE LATAPE
Before every lacrosse-game the
opposing goalies shake hands at
midfield and proceed to their
respective 'creases. Each spring
Saturday for the past two years,
Les Matthews has performed this
ritual for the Johns Hopkins Blue
Jays.
A graduate of St. Paul's
School, Matthews has been at
home in the crease ever since the
third grade and has become most
proficient at that position in the
fourteen intervening years. His
talents have not gone unnoticed,
s Les was named the
outstanding collegiate goalkeeper
in the nation last year, winning
the C. Markland Kelly Award.
"Goalie is the most challenging
position because you are the last
barrier between the other team
and a score," stated the first
team All-American who is a
co-captain of the 1973 Blue Jays.
"But when you do well, it gives
you a lot of personal
satisfaction."
At St. Paul's, Matthews was
All-MSA goalie for two years. In

his senior year there, he was
captain of his lacrosse team, an
honorable mention All-State
halfback in football, and was
named the outstanding high
school lacrosse player in
Maryland. In addition to
continuing lacrosse at Hopkins,
Les has been a housemaster,
played football, and is a member
of the H Club and the Phi Gam
Fraternity.
Heavily recruited by several
schools, Matthews chose Hopkins
over the Ivy League for two
reasons. He felt that Hopkins
offered the best combination of
academics and lacrosse.
Moreover, since he had seen
every home Blue Jay lacrosse
game while in high school, he felt
he belonged here.
And he has not been
disappointed. "The quality of
education at Hopkins is as good
as that of the Ivies, plus there is
more personal contact with the
faculty and administration,"
enthused the natural sciences
area major."In addition, you can
do as much with a degree from

By STEVEN BROWN
Wednesday afternoon the Blue
Jay baseball team played their
wildest game of the season. The
game was called a forfeit in the
top of the eighth inning with
Hopkins in front, 16-9. The
Dickinson coach, angered by
some earlier calls made by the
plate umpire, protested a low
strike a little too loudly. After a
few words with the coach, the
umpire stopped the game and
awarded Hopkins the win. The
victory was highly appreciated
after the Jays dropped both ends
of a double header against
Loyola the day before, 9-1 and
5-3.
On Tuesday the Blue Jays ran
into some tough Loyola pitching.
In the first game, Loyola's
mound star fanned twelve batters
and allowed only four hits.
Loyola exploded for eight runs in
the first two innings on only
three hits. The lone Blue Jay run
was scored in the fourth as Jack
Bukowski singled, Mike Bogdan
walked and Gary Rostkowski
followed with a single, scoring
the lead runner.

Hopkins as with one from
Princeton or the other Ivy
League schools."
Renowned for his long clearing
passes, Matthews credits his
attackmen and the plastic stick
for the successful maneuver. "It's
difficult to catch the ball with a
defenseman bearing down on
you," said Les when referring to
the ability of the attackmen to
handle his bombs. "But the
plastic stick makes a longer and
more accurate throw possible."
According to Matthews, the
difference between the 1972 and
1973 lacrosse teams is that this
year the Blue Jays have more
depth. "The defense is also now
as good as the 1972 version,

although it took us a while to get
our' timing and coordination
down," sighed Matthews.
Commenting on his coach, Les
stated, "Mr. Scott is the best.
Period. He's not only a great
strategist, but the best at mental
preparation." With the likes of
Joe Cowan, Jerry Schnydman,
Fred Smith, Buzzy Budnitz, and
Willie Scroggs aiding Scott,
Hopkins has the best coaching
staff in the country.
Matthews stressed the
importance of fan support to the
team. "We've had great support
wherever we've gone. Cornell this
year and Virginia last year stick
out the most. The crowd is worth
a couple of goals a game."

By BILL SCHOEFFLER
With the arrival of
Homecoming Weekend, alumni
from around the country are
converging on Baltimore to meet
old classmates, relive college
memories, and watch the Johns
Hopkins lacrosse team attempt to
make Navy its ninth consecutive
victim of the year tomorrow
afternoon at Homewood Field.
The faceoff will follow the 1:30
Parade of the Classes and other
Homecoming festivities.
Over the years Navy has not
been an obliging Homecoming
guest, as the Blue Jays have
beaten the Midshipmen here only
twice in the last twenty years. In
fact, they are the only major
college opponent to hold an edge
over Hopkins in the series rivalry.
The Blue Jays have won 19, lost
24 and tied one in the 44
previous meetings of the two
schools.

After this weekend, the Blue

the regular season card. That will
be against the Terrapins of

final at Philadelphia.

at every position, but is
particularly impressive in the
midfields, where many games are

Championship Tournament.

Sunday and eight teams will take
part in the competition. Current
speculation, which is certain to
be effected by the results of the
next ten days, suggests that
Hopkins, Maryland, and Virginia
are certain participants; Hofstra,
Brown, Army, and Washington &
Lee are probable entrants; and
Cortland State, Rutgers, and
Navy are possible selections.

&S graduate stipends cut $170,000
By BILL ABBOTT
The equivalent to 85 graduate
qipends at $2000 per annum has
fallen under the budget ax in. the
Arts and Sciences division,
according to Dean George Owen.
Owen attributed the $170,000
bullet bite in University stipend
assistance -- 20 percent the A&S
Stipend budget -- to the $300
tuition increase and anticipated
federal cutbacks.
the "It is generally recognized that
all the days grad students can
depend on the University, the
federal government, or both to
day
Lred fully support them are just about
irne Over," commented Larry Denton,
assistant to Homewood
Vice-President George Benton.
"With the increase in tuition
and the elimination of some
federal support," Denton added,

for
ved
ces
ose
25,

"we'll either have fewer grad
students or more supporting
themselves."
Denton estimated that 1
percent of Homewood's 970
graduate students currently pay
their own tuition. He speculated
that graduate enrollment next
September would decline to
about 900.
The University will increase its
spending for graduate aid next
year by $130,000, bringing its
total support to $2.42 million.
Owen explained this increase and
funds gained from the stipend
cut will be directed into the
Gilman Fellowship program, the
University's grad student tuition
assistance effort.
Denton admitted, however,
that the added $300,000 will not
be enough to fully support the

tuition needs of all Homewood
graduate students. And, by
Denton's estimate, 50 percent of
all grads now receiving stipends
had to secure outside loans
because the levels of stipend
support "couldn't support the
lowest standard of living."
One source in the Political
Science department maintained
that graduate stipends were being
cut from $2200 to $2000, and
that first year students who had
taken out loans in anticipation of
some stipend suppoi-t next year
would not get any.
Benton, whose office
determined that the University
would award the $2.42 million in
University funds, asserted that all
departments would feel the
pinch.
"We've tried to spread the pain

as evenly as possible," Benton
said, explaining that departments
which will not be affected by
federal funding cutbacks would
have to suffer at the expense of
those which are.
One source of federal funding
tapped for termination by the
new Nixon budget is the US
Public Health training grant. The
departments of Psychology,
Social Relations, Biology, and
Biophysics currently receive
$800,000 for graduate student
support through the training
grant program.
Psychology, the only
department with training grants
up for renewal this year,
anticipated to lose all of its
$67,000 now used to support 16
graduate students. However, last
Friday, department chairman

Dean George uwen
William Garvey was informed all
previous notices of curtailment
were "inoperative," and that
Psychology would be able to
support those students to whom
training grant assistance had been
committed prior to April 23 for
their graduate career.

Class of '77 has fewer pre-meds
By B.H. COHEN
This fall's incoming freshman
class, anticipated to be the largest
since the GI-bill days
immediately after World War II,
may include fewer Natural
Science and pre-medical students
than the current freshman class.
Already, 598 of the 1375
applicants accepted for the class
of 1977 have filed their $100
deposits, and additional deposits
are expected to arrive over the

next several days. In addition,
approximately 10 of the
accepted applicants have been
given extensions beyond
Tuesday's May 1 deadline for
filing deposits.
Last year, according to
Admissions and Financial Aid
Director John R. Riina, 578
students had returned deposits
by May 3, though that figure rose
to 588 at one point last May. 557
students enrolled as freshmen last
summer, some 22 more than
anticipated.
One admissions officer stated
that he expects about 618
students to file deposits by the
end of the month.
"There will be some attrition
in our yield," Riina commented
yesterday.
Figures released by Riina
indicate that the number of
Natural Science and pre-med
majors will decline somewhat
from the level of the current
freshman class. "I'm impressed
with the fact that we have fewer

pre-meds in this incoming class,
even though the total number of
students will go up," Riina
commented.
Last year at this time, 249
pre -meds had filed deposits.
Through yesterday, 243 pre-meds
had filed.
Prospective Natural Science
enrollees have fallen from 349
last year, to 335 this year, while
depositers: in the Social and
Behavioral Sciences have gone up
from 111 to 135.
In addition, tlumanities,
Engineering, and Quantitative
Studies depositers have increased
somewhat over last year's level.
[See figures, page 61
"We have more numbers vhere
we wanted better percentages,
and less where we wanted to see
a reduction," Riina explained.

year that Admissions, acting
under the guidance of

discipline code'til fall

By ALLEN SHORT
Homewood Advisory Councii
flAC) action on the new Code
Student Rights and
isciplinary Procedures appears
.ghly unlikely this semester as,

I

On

the result of a Student Council
decision postponing its
consideration of the code until
after next fall's frosh elections.
The HAC had -earlier deferred .
action on the code pending SC

Andrew S'avilz

approval and open hearings.
According to SC president
Andrew W. Savitz, the decision
reflects an SC concensus of
opinion that "The undergraduate
student body hasn't had the time
orthe opportunity to adequately
study the code."
During the discussion which
preceded the tabling decision
Tuesday night, Council members
debated the necessity of having a
discipline code.
•
Committee Came
Said HAC undergrad
representative Howard Majev,
"The Discipline Committee came
to us and said that a code was
needed, but they never said
why."
According to senior class

president-elect Shep Hoffman, a
member of the Discipline
Committee, "The present interim
code, implemented by (Arts &
Sciences) Dean Benton in 1970,
would have remained in effect
had we not come up with a new
one. We found it particularly
distasteful."
Eyes And Ears
In a related action yesterday,
some twenty-five students
attended the open hearing on the
Discipline Code and voiced
considerable dissatisfaction with
several of its provisions.
Leon Barish, newly-elected
junior class SC representative,
objected to the code's
enumeration of specific
violations, especially one

prohibiting "Illegal possession,
use, or sale of drugs or liquor on
campus." He maintained that the
provision, if enforced, would
eliminate the serving of beer -at
Sunday afternoon concerts. If
the provision is not to be
enforced, he continued, "there is
just no reason to have it in '
there."
Dean of Students Robert J.
Fitzpatrick stated that he will
recommend to the HAC next
Thursday that action on the code
be deferred until after the
beginning of next semester.
After approval has been given
to the code, in its original or
revised version, said Fitzpatrick,
it should be implemented on a
temporary basis.

Homecoming fetes
alums this week-end
By JERRY NESER
This weekend's 1973
Homecoming festivities,
sPonsored by the Office of
Alumni Relations, will include
the annual Alumni Relations
Dinner, a luncheon, and campus
tours, according to Edward 0.
Nicholas, Homecoming
Chairman.
Other features of the weekend
Will include Saturday's lacrosse
game against Navy, and reunions
of the classes whose graduating
Years end in "3" or "8", the
Oldest class represented will be
that of 1903.
"The Homecoming is geared
towards those reunion classes,"
said Bill Van Diepen, assistant
director of Alumni Relations.
The class of 1923 will definitely
be the most highlighted class,
though," he added.
Lo-Cal Desert
The Alumni Association
Dinner, to be held this evening at
the Hunt Valley Inn in
Cockeysville, will feature as
Speakers President Muller and
Louis Koerber, Alumni
Association President. Also, the
Distinguished Alumnus Awards
Will be presented during the
dinner.
Receiving the Alumni Awards

will be Albert D. Hutzler,
president of Hutzler's Brothers
and retired alumni trustee,
Edward Schaefer, an industrialist
from Indiana, and Donald
Wilson, president of Monumental
Life Insurance Company and
retiring president of the Alumni
Association.
The luncheon will be held on
Saturday afternoon with the
traditional crabcake meal
planned. Afterwards, the reunion
classes will proceed to the
Homewood Field Granstands
where the Class of 1923 will
receive 50-year medallions.
Lunchmeat
"The luncheon this year is sold
out," explained Van Diepen. "It
hasn't been sold out in years, but
we are expecting some 1500
people," he added.
Following the lacrosse game,
the Hopkins fraternities will hole
open houses for the alumni.
Saturday evening the reunion
classes will hold dinner dances
and parties on campus.
"All that I hope of the
Hopkins students is that they
remember that it is Hopkins
Alumni Homecoming," asserted
Van Diepen. "I hope that they
will cooperate with us during this
weekend," he added.

Warren to speak at graduation
Earl Warren, former Chief
Justice of the United States will
be the featured speaker at
Commencement exercises on
Friday, May 25. Warren has also
served as Attorney General and
Governor of California.
Beginning at 9:30 am the
ceremony will take place in the
Keyser quadrangle between
Gilman Hall and the Milton S.
Eisenhower Library. President
Muller will preside over the
ceremony.
During the exercises, degrees
will be conferred upon
candidates from the Medical,
• W4
,151,-.1,

Arts and Sciences, Hygiene,
Evening College, and
International Studies divisions. A
total of 2,304 degrees are
expected to be given. In addition,
472 advanced degrees will be
awarded.
tent, capable of covering
four thousand people, will be
erected so that the event may be
held outdoors, regardless of
weather.
Successful candidates for the
B.A. and the B.E.S. will have
their diplomas presented to them
at a separate ceremony on
Thursday, May 24. The featured
A

speaker will be Victor Zorza,
noted syndicated columnist and
lecturere at the School of
Advanced International Studies.
Zorza is a designer and expert in
the field of "predictive analysis."
He has gained widespread
recognition for his predictions of
some of the most unexpected
international developments in
recent years, such as the
Sino-Soviet dispute and the fall
of Soviet leader Nikita
Khruschev.
Also to receive honorary
degrees at Commencement day
ceremonies are two faculty
members emerit. Their names
were not available yesterday
since the Board of Trustees must
grant formal approval with the
awarding of the degrees. The
Board next meets on May 14.
Singing
Traditional parts of the
two-day ceremoney will include
the procession of berobed
University officials, faculty
members and graduates, and the
singing of the University ode.

FROSH, from page 1

I

more deposits than anticipated
from prospective freshmen. Last
Year, Admissions was aiming for
35 enrollees. And letters to high
school guidance counsellors,
mailed early in April this year,
read in part, "only 530 places are
available for freshmen."
Student Council President
Andrew W. Savitz, reached last
Right, commented, "I'm happy
to hear that the pre-med and
natural science percentages have
gone down.
"But I hope that the Housing
,Office is able to find space for all
the freshmen next fall," he
added.
Other information released by

Riina indicates that the number
of first-year women will remain
at its present level, and that black
freshmen may increase. While
only 14 blacks enrolled last fall,
23 have already filed deposits
this year.
Five high schoolers have
elected to defer their
matriculation by up to two years,
in a newly-instituted program.
They are not included in the 598
depositors.
Riina stated that this year's
yield to date is 43.5 percent of
all accepted students, up from
last year's 40.8 percent.
However, only 78 of the top
202 applicants to this fall's class,
or 38.6 percent, Filed deposits.

goodbye, goodbye
Bob Hewes' Office of Public Information doesn't keep
statistics on them, but Hopkins officials have been disappearing from their desks at an alarming rate this year, some
moving upstairs and some just moving. This bureaucratic
phenomeno, often referred to as "the screw," rarely merits
a press release or a big story (with picture) in the Gazette.
We wonder a little how these folks are ever going to be
found when the University makes so little effort to let us
know where they went.
As a public service to our readers, we are today printing a
list of the missing and their fates in our last issue of the
year. Among the missing:
Budget Director Benjamin Ge. Willis, whose disappearance caused Garland Hall morale to plummet, disappeared
after Hopkins had its first balanced budget in five years.
Development Director David W. Ellis got lost among the
Hopkins Hundreds.
Director of Student Activities and of the Hopkins Union
Jim Sydnor, will soon get lost.
Director of Athletics Marshall S. Turner, Jr., will warm
the bench for up to two years before retirement from the
Athletic Center.
MSE Librarian John H. Berthel now keeps track of the
University Library in Garland Hall.
If the new discipline code is ever promulgated, students
may disappear ahnost as fast.

Four Hop profs elected to National Academy of Sciences
Four Hopkins professors were
among the 95 new members
elected last month to the
National Academy of Sciences.
The elections of Homewood
professors Donald D. Brown,
Biology, Robert G. Parr,
Chemistry, and Medical School
faculty members Victor A.
McKusick, professor of medicine
and Helen B. Taussig, professor
emeritus of pediatrics, bring the
total membership in the
Academy to 1,012, according to
Dr. Philip S. Handler, Academy
president.
Election to membership in the
National Academy of Sciences is
considered one of the highest
honors that can be accorded an
American scientist or engineer.
Brown, a developmental
biologist, joined the U.S. Public
Health Service Natioal Institute
of Mental Health in 1957 as S.A.
surgeon and research associate. In
1959 he was appointed Special

Medical School in 1946, he was a
member of the house staff until
1951, when he was named
instructor. He was appointed
professor of medicine in 1960
and currently holds joint
appointments in biology in the
Arts and Sciences and
epidemiology at the School of
Hygiene and Public Health.

McKusick is chief of the Division
of Medical Genetics at the School
of Medicine.
McKusick's well-known
investigations include a long-term
study of hereditary diseases
among the Amish and a study of
the x chromosomes in man.
Parr joined the faculty of the

in 1947 as assistant professor and

Parr was a Guggenheim Fellow

National Science Foundation

University of Oxford in

Hopkins faculty in 1962. From
1969 until last June, Parr served
as chairman of the Chemistry

Study at Hopkins of hemoglobin molecule yields results
A team of Hopkins
biophysicists has obtained new
data on the structure of the
sickle cell hemoglobin molecule
in the critical deoxygenated
state.
The new information was
obtained through th6 technique of
x-ray diffraction of crystallized
sickle cells.
The research group is headed
by Warner E. Love, professor and
chairman of the Department of
Biophysics and includes Eato
Lattman, a research associate,
and graduate students Keith
Ward and Barry Wishner.
Hemoglobin moleules, both
normal and sickle cell, exist in
two states in the blood stream:
oxygenated after passing through
the lungs, and deoxygenated
after they have released the
oxygen at some point in the
body.
The latter is the important
state as far as study of the
diseased molecule is concerned.
It is in this deoxygenated state

that the molecules stick together
and distort the red blood cell in
which they are contained. This
causes the painful "sickle cell
crisis" in sickle cell anemia. The
anemia is a hereditary disease
which affects approximately one
black person in forty.
According to Love, electron
microscopy does not yield
sufficient detail to reveal the
atomic structure of the molecules
and up to now,it has not been
possible to analyze them by x-ray
diffraction because of technical
difficulties in crystalizing
deoxygenated sickle cell
hemoglobin. The crystalization
process is a prerequisite for
employment of the x-ray
diffraction. Love began working
on the sickle cell problem nearly
two years ago. The research
group's initial success came last
year in January when Wishner
succeeded in growing diffraction
quality crystals of deoxygenated
sickle cell hemoglobin. As a
result of the advance, Love's

$209,000 from the National
Institutes of Health to support
further study.
A second breakthrough was
recorded last month when the
researchers discovered the proper
position of the molecule in its
crystal lattice. The problem was
achieved with the aid of
computer facilities at Hopkins
Applied Physics Lab.
Love explained that there was
an element of risk involved in the
study. "It is possible
in the
process of crystalization," he
*said, "that the hemoglobin
molecules may be altered such
that they no longer represent
what actually goes on in the
human blood stream." But Love
added that his group was hopeful
that in their study of the
molecule's crystalline structure
they will in fact come up with a
true picture of what the sickled
hemoglobin molecule looks like.
The end product of the
diffraction analysis will be a

THE PSYCHOLOGY CENTER has completed its
most unusual assignment — the ADULT I.Q. TEST. It
is unusual in its approach to intelligence testing.
Any test that relies on either memorization or recall
is basically an inaccurate and unreliable indicator of
intelligence. Unfortunately, this type of test is
prevalent throughout our educationai system. The
ADULT I.Q. TEST, however, is composed of
questions that are specially designed to probe and
challenge the intellect in order to reveal its ability to
think. For this reason, the ADULT I.Q. TEST is a
true intelligence test.

Matthews stands tall as best of 'last barrier
By MIKE LATAPE
Before every lacrosse-game the
opposing goalies shake hands at
midfield and proceed to their
respective 'creases. Each spring
Saturday for the past two years,
Les Matthews has performed this
ritual for the Johns Hopkins Blue
Jays.
A graduate of St. Paul's
School, Matthews has been at
home in the crease ever since the
third grade and has become most
proficient at that position in the
fourteen intervening years. His
talents have not gone unnoticed,
s Les was named the
outstanding collegiate goalkeeper
in the nation last year, winning
the C. Markland Kelly Award.
"Goalie is the most challenging
position because you are the last
barrier between the other team
and a score," stated the first
team All-American who is a
co-captain of the 1973 Blue Jays.
"But when you do well, it gives
you a lot of personal
satisfaction."
At St. Paul's, Matthews was
All-MSA goalie for two years. In

his senior year there, he was
captain of his lacrosse team, an
honorable mention All-State
halfback in football, and was
named the outstanding high
school lacrosse player in
Maryland. In addition to
continuing lacrosse at Hopkins,
Les has been a housemaster,
played football, and is a member
of the H Club and the Phi Gam
Fraternity.
Heavily recruited by several
schools, Matthews chose Hopkins
over the Ivy League for two
reasons. He felt that Hopkins
offered the best combination of
academics and lacrosse.
Moreover, since he had seen
every home Blue Jay lacrosse
game while in high school, he felt
he belonged here.
And he has not been
disappointed. "The quality of
education at Hopkins is as good
as that of the Ivies, plus there is
more personal contact with the
faculty and administration,"
enthused the natural sciences
area major."In addition, you can
do as much with a degree from

By STEVEN BROWN
Wednesday afternoon the Blue
Jay baseball team played their
wildest game of the season. The
game was called a forfeit in the
top of the eighth inning with
Hopkins in front, 16-9. The
Dickinson coach, angered by
some earlier calls made by the
plate umpire, protested a low
strike a little too loudly. After a
few words with the coach, the
umpire stopped the game and
awarded Hopkins the win. The
victory was highly appreciated
after the Jays dropped both ends
of a double header against
Loyola the day before, 9-1 and
5-3.
On Tuesday the Blue Jays ran
into some tough Loyola pitching.
In the first game, Loyola's
mound star fanned twelve batters
and allowed only four hits.
Loyola exploded for eight runs in
the first two innings on only
three hits. The lone Blue Jay run
was scored in the fourth as Jack
Bukowski singled, Mike Bogdan
walked and Gary Rostkowski
followed with a single, scoring
the lead runner.

Renowned for his long clearing
passes, Matthews credits his
attackmen and the plastic stick
for the successful maneuver. "It's
difficult to catch the ball with a
defenseman bearing down on
you," said Les when referring to
the ability of the attackmen to
handle his bombs. "But the
plastic stick makes a longer and
more accurate throw possible."
According to Matthews, the
difference between the 1972 and
1973 lacrosse teams is that this
year the Blue Jays have more
depth. "The defense is also now
as good as the 1972 version,

although it took us a while to get
our' timing and coordination
down," sighed Matthews.
Commenting on his coach, Les
stated, "Mr. Scott is the best.
Period. He's not only a great
strategist, but the best at mental
preparation." With the likes of
Joe Cowan, Jerry Schnydman,
Fred Smith, Buzzy Budnitz, and
Willie Scroggs aiding Scott,
Hopkins has the best coaching
staff in the country.
Matthews stressed the
importance of fan support to the
team. "We've had great support
wherever we've gone. Cornell this
year and Virginia last year stick
out the most. The crowd is worth
a couple of goals a game."

Homecoming Weekend, alumni
from around the country are
converging on Baltimore to meet
old classmates, relive college
memories, and watch the Johns
Hopkins lacrosse team attempt to
make Navy its ninth consecutive
victim of the year tomorrow
afternoon at Homewood Field.

Parade of the Classes and other
Homecoming festivities.
Over the years Navy has not
been an obliging Homecoming
guest, as the Blue Jays have
beaten the Midshipmen here only
twice in the last twenty years. In
fact, they are the only major
college opponent to hold an edge
over Hopkins in the series rivalry.
The Blue Jays have won 19, lost
24 and tied one in the 44
previous meetings of the two
schools.

another slight and quick goalie,

After this weekend, the Blue
Jays have one game remaining on
the regular season card. That will
be against the Terrapins of
Maryland in what many believe
will be a preview of the NCAA
final at Philadelphia.
Maryland has depth and talent
at every position, but is
particularly impressive in the
midfields, where many games are
won or lost. Among the featured
players in College Park are Frank

respectively, last year.

attention will turn to the NCAA
Championship Tournament.

Sunday and eight teams will take
part in the competition. Current
speculation, which is certain to
be effected by the results of the
next ten days, suggests that
Hopkins, Maryland, and Virginia
are certain participants; Hofstra,
Brown, Army, and Washington &
Lee are probable entrants; and
Cortland State, Rutgers, and
Navy are possible selections.
